As a chemistry tutor with an amateur interest in linguistics, this is the best year of Crash Course ever!

One of the things I'm interested to learn in this course is what constitutes a language vs a method/medium for communicating. Of the 7,000 languages identified, including thousands of spoken languages, and hundreds of sign languages, what are the edge cases like and what distinguishes them or makes them a tough call? For example, written language seems to be shaped by its medium in that in hand writing a book, monks used a shorthand that would be nonsensical to pronounce rather than the words they represent. In text messages on flip phones, a new form of shorthand arrived based on the tediousness of input style. Smoke signals are communicative and (I'm guessing I don't know much about them) have some defined set of symbols but it is heavily reliant on the nature of the medium. Is this one of the symbolic languages? Since the meaning being conveyed in body language is most accurately measured statistically, as specifically people sometimes refuse to express what they want to communicate in body language with any other form and confirmation can be hard to get, does this count as language? If so, does it have higher order structures like grammer (like first I huff and then I stomp my feet, and then I slam a door; or first I smile, and then I wink, and then I lean in for a kiss)?
I am so glad that it's been like 3 years since I've last had to talk to people to order pizza.
I’VE BEEN PREPARING MY WHOLE INTERNET LIFE FOR THIS

This probably couldn't have come at a better time for me..As I sit and wait for things to clear a little and figure out how to go about a Bachelors for Art, I am holding myself over with multiple foreign languages on DuoLingo..and I am contending with a grand total of 9 languages..

German (done once already but redoing..and nearly finished).., Norwegian (Complete), Scottish Gaelic, Finnish (It may see a redo after I'm done because its a recently released course..), Arabic (I have to redo this one because it expanded when I was done with it originally..and it might be several times because it still doesn't seem like a complete skill tree to me..), Romanian, Czech, Russian, Hindi, and Japanese (I started on it but couldn't focus on it enough because of Norwegian at the time..)..

DuoLingo is completely free, for anyone interested..unless you try to get Premium of course..At present time, my DuoLingo day streak is 396 days..I am literally in linguistic hell as a hobby..

Fingers crossed that this includes the topic of how technology affects language. Writing, radio, TV, the internet, and now voice assistants all have and will continue to have major impacts on language. The generations growing up with voice assistants will have how they speak affected because they grew up trying to be heard and understood by voice technology, and as that tech improves language will change again to keep up!

My only request is that you explain how linguistics is descriptive rather than prescriptive, and how the prescriptivism so many people espouse (quoting the presence of words in dictionaries, etc.) is anti-science. So many people use language only as a tool to attempt feeling superior, instead of loving it for the complex, organic, messy, nuanced and nebulous phenomenon that it is. People argue about denotative meanings and ignore connotation. People quibble about prepositions at the ends of sentences and conjunctions at their beginnings. I think the most important lesson that the public could ever be given would be to do away with that preconception about language.

I can say I have a bit of a passing interest in conlangs and seeing what kinds of interesting structures are possible that we may not see in the languages we're familiar with.
While languages often spend time focusing on the various sounds they use, it's still interesting how many languages out there, including some that might not even be called languages in most contexts, simply don't use sound. Sign language is probably the most obvious one, but body language is arguably its own language in this category as well. Then as you get further and further away from what's typically called a language, you start running into questions like whether or not emoji should be classified as high-tech hieroglyphics, but with an emphasis on conveying tone in addition to the literal meaning. Should mathematical notation be called a language? If not, then where does Lojban fall into? If Lojban is considered a language, then would the various programming languages be as well? While they all look so different from natural or spoken languages, they still manage to have familiar elements that manage to link it back.
While many would probably consider this out-of-scope for linguistics, I always tend to enjoy diving into the extremes of a topic to find just where the boundary truly is.
